results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Basketball;Awards, Decorations and Honors;Content Type: Personal Profile;Curry, Stephen;Davidson College;Golden State Warriors
results.byline: By Anna Katherine Clemmons and Travis Dove
results.title: Stephen Curry Said Davidson Changed His Life. He Changed Davidson.
results.abstract: Curry, the N.B.A. superstar, returned to Davidson College, where he first showed how great he could be. The college, and its community, still feel his impact over a decade later.

media.caption: Stephen Curry said going to Davidson College “was kind of the beginning of a major evolution in my life.” It started an evolution for the school, too.

results.adx_keywords: Television;Burns, Ken;Novick, Lynn;Mendelsohn, Daniel;Ward, Geoffrey C;Botstein, Sarah (1972- );Public Broadcasting Service
results.title: Ken Burns Explores America’s Inaction During the Holocaust
results.abstract: “The U.S. and the Holocaust,” coming to PBS Sept. 18, examines the reasons behind the country’s inadequate response to Germany’s persecution of Jews.

media.caption: “The U.S. and the Holocaust” is Ken Burns’s latest deep dive into America’s past.

results.adx_keywords: Artificial Intelligence;Art;State and County Fairs;Contests and Prizes;Midjourney Inc;Colorado
results.title: An A.I.-Generated Picture Won an Art Prize. Artists Aren’t Happy.
results.abstract: “I won, and I didn’t break any rules,” the artwork’s creator says.

media.caption: Jason Allen’s A.I.-generated work, “Théâtre D’opéra Spatial,” took first place in the digital category at the Colorado State Fair.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Writing and Writers;Books and Literature;Labor and Jobs;United States Economy;Wages and Salaries;Income Inequality;News and News Media;Ehrenreich, Barbara
results.title: Barbara Ehrenreich, Explorer of Prosperity’s Dark Side, Dies at 81
results.abstract: Her book “Nickel and Dimed,” an undercover account of the indignities of being a low-wage worker in the United States, is considered a classic in social justice literature.

media.caption: The author Barbara Ehrenreich in 2020. She tackled a variety of themes: the myth of the American dream, the labor market, health care, poverty and women’s rights.

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Coronavirus Reopenings;Seattle (Wash)
results.title: In Seattle, It’s Almost Normal
results.abstract: The pandemic may have left some gaps in the urban fabric, but a neighborhood-by-neighborhood rundown of new restaurants and art events reveals that recovery is well underway.

media.caption: The Space Needle in downtown Seattle. With the removal of the elevated highway known as the Alaskan Way Viaduct, the city’s waterfront is undergoing a renewal.

results.adx_keywords: internal-sub-only;Rivers;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Conservation of Resources;Fishing, Sport;Trout;Rafts;Land Use Policies;Water;Colorado;Arkansas River
results.title: Does This Fisherman Have the Right to Be in a Billionaire’s Backyard?
results.abstract: A fight along Colorado’s waterways pits an alliance of white-water rafters and amateur anglers against some of the nation’s wealthiest landowners, bruising the image of a sportsman’s paradise.

media.caption: Roger Hill, a fly fisherman, in the Arkansas River east of Cotopaxi, Colo. He has sued to have the state clarify its laws around one of his favorite fly-fishing grounds.
media.copyright: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Bars and Nightclubs;Restaurants;Electric Light and Power;Natural Gas;Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);Shutdowns (Institutional);Great Britain
results.title: Britain’s Pubs Are Threatened by ‘Alarming’ Rise in Energy Bills
results.abstract: Businesses have fewer protections than residential users against higher electricity and gas costs, and industry groups warn of widespread closings this winter.

media.caption: A pub on Carnaby Street in London. The industry has called for “swift and substantial” government intervention to help pubs deal with energy bills.
media.copyright: Alice Zoo for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: internal-storyline-no;Pickleball (Sport);Sprains and Strains
results.title: Game On
results.abstract: It’s Labor Day weekend, the perfect time to try — you guessed it — pickleball.

results.adx_keywords: Trees and Shrubs;Forests and Forestry;Content Type: Personal Profile;Conservation of Resources;internal-sub-only;Gowda, Tulsi Gowind;India;Karnataka (India)
results.title: ‘Magic in Her Hands.’ The Woman Bringing India’s Forests Back to Life
results.abstract: Tulsi Gowind Gowda has spent most of her more than 80 years planting and nurturing trees in southern India. “I like them more than anything else in my life,” she said.

media.caption: Tulsi Gowda has devoted her life to transforming barren land into dense forests in Karnataka, a state in southern India.
media.copyright: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times

results.title: Lawsuits Over Tragedies Can Drag On. Not in the Florida Condo Collapse.
results.abstract: A little over a year after the Champlain Towers South fell, the Surfside condo victims’ families are about to be compensated for their losses.

media.copyright: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Children and Childhood;Happiness
results.title: How to Have Fun Again
results.abstract: An illustrated guide to letting loose.

results.adx_keywords: Vaccination and Immunization;Coronavirus Omicron Variant;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)
results.title: What to Know About the New Booster Shots
results.abstract: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.

media.caption: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Television;Gambling;Retirement Communities and Assisted Living;Alzheimer's Disease;Content Type: Personal Profile;Milch, David
results.title: David Milch Still Has Stories to Tell
results.abstract: The TV producer and creator of “Deadwood” recounts his tumultuous upbringing, his trailblazing career and his experience with Alzheimer’s disease in “Life’s Work.”

media.caption: “I have lived into the vivid truth that we’re in the last innings,” Milch said. “So, be grateful, because you ought to be. There are so many gestures of kindness and humane connection.”
media.copyright: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Elderly;Generation X;Retirement;Volunteers and Community Service;Village to Village Network
results.title: Generation X Volunteers Want to Help You, and One Day Themselves, Age at Home
results.abstract: The Village to Village Network assists older people with the services they need to remain in their homes. A younger generation is getting involved.

media.caption: Conner Sandefur, with his wife, Brittany. Mr. Sandefur, 44, volunteers with Fearrington Cares, part of a village in Pittsboro, N.C.
media.copyright: Kate Medley for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Wordle (Puzzle);Games
results.title: Few Wordle Players Use Consistent Starting Words, but When They Do, It’s ADIEU
results.abstract: What the data tells us about how people play the game.

media.caption: Wordle gives players six tries to guess the daily word. Only a small number of people go in with a plan.

results.title: A Tiny House in Manhattan Has a Link to the Underground Railroad
results.abstract: Before it was a clothing store, it was a bar, and before it was a bar, it was a key part of American history.

media.caption: The frame house at the intersection of White St. and West Broadway in Tribeca has served a variety of purposes since its construction in 1809.
media.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Dating and Relationships;Friendship
results.title: The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness
results.abstract: New research shows small gestures matter even more than we may think.

results.adx_keywords: Pickleball (Sport);Tennis;Seattle (Wash)
results.title: Can a Tennis Player Share His Heart, and Courts, With Pickleball?
results.abstract: Our columnist grew up playing competitive tennis on Seattle courts that are now caught in the middle of a turf war with pickleball. He took up a paddle to see what all the fuss was about.

media.caption: Our columnist playing pickleball. It was competitive but not so rigorous that he couldn’t wear his straw, wide-brimmed hat while playing, he said.
media.copyright: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times

results.title: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
results.abstract: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.

media.copyright: Kim Raff for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Theater;Transgender and Transsexuals;Gender;Women's Rights;Josephine, Charlie;Terry, Michelle (1979- );Joan of Arc;Globe Theater;London (England)
results.title: At Shakespeare’s Globe, a Nonbinary Joan of Arc Causes a Stir
results.abstract: Even before the production debuted, it had inflamed a rancorous debate about sex and gender that plays out almost daily in Britain.

media.caption: Joan of Arc is played as a nonbinary person by Isobel Thom in “I, Joan,” a Shakespeare’s Globe production in London.
